utterances: (Soundbite of laughter)
Ah, you know, no more pantsuits, and especially in orange.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Which was, of course...
But, that's just a personal taste thing, that's just a personal taste thing.
For those who are listening on the radio last night, orange was the color of the pantsuit that she wore at the Democratic National Convention last night.
We're talking with Lizz Winstead and with Susan Faludi.
We're discussing what Senator Clinton's campaign meant for woman and for feminism.
If you'd like to join us, 800-989-8255.
Email us at talk@npr.org and you're listening to Talk of the Nation from NPR News.
And let's get another caller on the line.
This is Nancy.
Nancy with us from Louisville in Kentucky.
Hi.
Hi.
My question is, I'm in the middle of the baby boom.
I'm 54 and I have not felt as strongly about Hillary the first woman, the feminist thing as some people around me who - everybody was shocked that I wasn't for Hillary.
And I've sensed they felt a whole lot stronger and they're slightly older than I am.
And I'm wondering if there's a breakdown, you know, baby boom, younger generation is different.
I just haven't heard any numbers, it's all treated like woman are all one age and I don't - I don't know if that's actually true or not.
I don't know whether woman of all ages feel the same way.
Lizz Winstead, what do you think?
I know you're not a pollster either.
I know I'm not a pollster.
I'm - I guess for me, I have never been a Hillary Clinton fan, sort of all along.
She never was my candidate and so, I guess I feel like generationally there is a big issue.
I think, you know, women identify with feminism so much differently now.
So many young woman don't identify with it at all and you know, it makes me think, for me I feel like getting 18 million votes is pretty awesome.
I mean, I think that's a pretty good sign that woman are seeing the feminist glass as half-full, thinking wow, Hillary is not the candidate for me right now.
But I do feel - I feel very comfortable that in my lifetime, I will see a woman as president.
Maybe, that's pie in the sky, but I do feel that way and I think that, you know, I think, to Susan's point when she said, you know, gosh, how unfortunate that we have these groundbreaking candidates.
We have an African-American man and a woman at a time when, you know, there are so many other things going on that we have to look at it.
And we have to look at the woman's war vote, we have to look at the woman's support of the bankruptcy bill, you know, we have to look at the African-American's experience and what we think that is.
And you know, it's a very - it's a difficult time to have groundbreaking candidates, I think.
Thanks very much for the call, Nancy.
And I want to hear from Susan Faludi on this point as well as from you, Lizz.
Do you think that we're in a post-feminist period?
Do you think that the battles of the '60s have been one and other things have happened?
And I just think back to some of the things that Susan was saying, about the wage gap growing over the past four years.
Yeah, we're hardly in some feminist Mecca here.
(Soundbite of laughter)

This term post-feminism, which by the way, as scholars and in particular Harvard Professor Nancy Cott pointed out, the term post-feminism was coined in the 1920s and looking back, that was hardly feminist Mecca either.
So, I think post-feminism is something that's trotted out to say, hey gals, you know, we don't have any problems anymore.
If you do, it's just your own individual problem, so you know, go home and shut up basically.
So no, I don't know think we're in a post-feminist age.
As far as - but you know, young woman are not surprisingly - some young woman, I know plenty of young woman who are very committed to feminist change, but are they the majority?
Probably not, in a culture that rewards young woman for distancing themselves from feminism.

Probably not, in a culture that tells woman to - has basically served up a kind of commercial form of woman's liberation, where you find yourself emancipated by advancing your self-esteem and feeling a sense of self empowerment by shopping or putting Botox in your face.

You know, in a culture that talks, that is fixated on individualism and celebrity and being the object of adulation, it's a hard sell to say, why don't you embrace a feminism that is collective and more anonymous and is about bread and butter issues.
Well...
(Singing) Who better for you than the boy, huh?
And we're going to hear about that when we get back after a short break.
Lizz Winstead, please stay with us and also stay with us Susan Faludi.
We're going to talk more about what Hillary Clinton's candidacy meant for woman's rights and for feminism, 800-989-8255.
Email us at talk@npr.org.
We'll take more comments from the audience here at the Newseum as well.
Stay with us, I'm Neal Conan.
It's the Talk of the Nation from NPR News.
(Soundbite of music)
Today, we're talking about Hillary Clinton and the meaning of her candidacy for women and for feminism, 800-989-8255 is the phone number, e-mail us, talk@npr.org.

Our guests are Susan Faludi, a journalist and author, a Pulitzer-Prize and National Book Critic Critics Circle award winner, author most recently of the ""The Terror Dream: Fear and Fantasy in Post-9/11 America."" She's with us from KQED, our member station in San Francisco.
Also with us Lizz Winstead, a comedian, writer and co-creator of ""The Daily Show,"" now a host of ""Thinking and Drinking with Lizz Winstead."" She's with us from Minneapolis.
And Lizz, just before the break you were describing a story that you thought was illustrative.
Oh, I have a talk show in New York and I invited on two women from Jezebel which is a, I guess, post-feminism website, and a very popular website with young women.

And the focus of that and that seems really prevalent for me, for a lot of young women, is this sort of freedom, sexual freedom, and its sole focus on just really aggressively sexual experiences, and equating that with feminism.
And I was sort of taken aback at the lack of responsibility that came with the advocating of sexual freedom and it was an eye-opening thing.
I felt really old and I felt really maternal.
So, I don't know - and I know that's just a small part of, sort of the landscape of what young feminism is today.
But it was - and I don't know if it's because sexual freedom is sort of an easy, an easy one to fight for.
You know, wage equity, you know, and workplace stuff is a little bit harder.
So I don't know where we're at in as far as where young women are putting their focus when it comes to feminist issues.
Well, joining us now is Amy Richards, co-author of the book ""Manifesta: Young Women, Feminism, and the Future,"" co-founder of the Third Wave Foundation, with us from our bureau in New York.
Nice to have you on the program today.
Thanks for having me.
And just to that point, is there a generational divide?
Well, I was just chuckling in my head because I was thinking, maybe the reason we don't think of Hillary Clinton as a feminist is because we don't think of her as sexual.
And maybe that explains why younger women feel disconnected, but I don't think there's truth to that.
And I am 38, so in the context of this conversation maybe feel a little bit young, but spend a lot of my time on college...
Congratulations.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Thanks.
But because I spend most of my time on college campuses, I actually feel like Lizz, very old and maternal when I'm speaking with college students.
And this primary season, I was very surprised at how many young people were as excited by Hillary Clinton's candidacy as they were by Barack Obama's candidacy.
And recalling my own first time voting, I said, you know, my choice was Dukakis.
And so, how exciting for them that they actually had two candidates that they were even excited about.

But I did not see so much of a age gap, I definitely felt the way it played out in the media, there was a lot more excitement for Hillary Clinton coming from the old guard of feminism and there was a lot more excitement for Obama among younger people.
But I saw an equal number of younger people excited by Hillary.
And bringing it back to, I think this concept of post-gender, I think if there's any way that - if there's any truth to this term, it's that we're evolving.
And I think that maybe up until this point, you'd see a candidacy like Hillary Clinton's or a candidacy like Barack Obama's primarily benefiting those constituencies.
Oh, we want to vote for Hillary Clinton because that will be good for women.
We want to vote for Barack Obama because that would be good for blacks in America, or good for non-white people.
And I think that we're reaching a point where recognizing that those candidates could just be good for America.
And I did a voter registration drive back in 1992 and I went into it thinking that I was helping voters who were not previously registered.
And I thought how good of me and noble of me to go into these underserved communities and help these voters get connected.
And it was kind of this epiphany halfway through where I went, oh my gosh, it actually is doing a disservice to me as an American if I live in a democracy that is not living up to that promise.
If I live in a democracy where not the full percent or even the majority of voters are voting.

And I think that's a little bit where we are with their candidacies right now, or with the kind of these races behind us and the midst of it is - oh, it could be good for all of us if there was somebody not male or not white who was president of the United States.
Here's an e-mail we have from Jane in Portland, Oregon, I'd like to read.
As a sixty-something white female, women's libber, my take on Hillary's candidacy is this, it wasn't overt or covert sexism of the media that did her in.
She didn't fail to win a nomination because reporters, for example, called attention to her cleavage; it was the sexism that she grew up with that did her in.
Like many of us, Hillary took a long time to figure out who she was, there's a long learning curve to this equality thing, as all depressed classes learn as they struggle on their way up.
Hillary got better and better and more sure-footed as she campaigned.
And last night, she showed everything that she had learned.
She's an object lesson for our generation and especially for the next.
I wonder, Susan Faludi, what you think of that?
Well, I think it's very true.
I think that was what was so moving about last night.
Was here is a woman who started out, you know, not an ideal public speaker.

A bit uncomfortable, and to see her evolve was thrilling and I think a great sense of encouragement to not just women, but women in particular who, you know, who enter on to the public stage for trepidation and who get knocked down.
And to see Hillary get knocked out time and again and get up and keep on fighting, as Harriet Tubman said, was very important for.
I mean, we don't even know that the young women out there who will take a lesson away from this and say, you know, maybe I'll try, too.
It's Candy and I just called, I've been listening this morning.

And I have to say I'm 38 years old and that's really embarrassing to say this, but until about a year, a year and a half ago, when I watched a documentary on HBO about Billie Jean King, I honestly had no clue how hard women had it.

I cried because here I have my mother-in-law and her partner who are total feminists and I was embarrassed that I went to college and I didn't realize, you know, what these women went through to get us where we're at.
And I honestly had to thank them when I saw them again and admitted that, you know, as bad as it may be, I had no idea.

And the horrible thing about is that it's almost going backwards, because I see in my nieces that they're so taking advantage of the freedoms that we have as women that they're actually focusing on more their sexuality and the attention that they're getting.
And I think that we need to just put our efforts into teaching our daughters, our nieces, our neighbor girls, anybody that, you know, is around.
Let them understand what we actually have went through to get to this point because, you know, as a 36-year-old woman, at the time when I saw this, I was just embarrassed and I understand it now.
And I think they would, too.
That's truly what we need to do, instead of, you know, taking our ball and going home, as the lady said before.
We need to just refocus our efforts in educating and continuing that education.
And that documentary reduced now to a television ad where Billie Jean King is in a tennis battle against, literally, a caveman.
I wonder, Amy Richards, what you thought of what Candy had to say.
Well, I think Candy - because we're at the same age, I think that some of our responsibility to feminism is acting on the rights that other generation fought so hard for.
And I hope that the way future generations express their feminism is both in the form of a thank you to Hillary Clinton and Shirley Chisholm and Pat Schroeder.
But also in the form of running for office, it's kind of doing what other generations could not do.
And so, I don't fault people so much for not appreciating or respecting enough what came before, but I do fault them for not being able to act upon what's in front of them.
How could you act upon it if you don't know it's there?
I would love to have the opportunity even in high school to have had a women's study class.
When I was in college, I didn't take any women's studies.
I chose other classes, but I think if it was something that was taught as early as high school we may, you know, be in a position to shape our lives so that we can act on that at an earlier age.
Well, Lizz Winstead, should American history include women's studies, it should be part of it?
Well, I think yes.
And the fact that we still live in a society where there's Women's History Month is a giant jumping off plan as a problem, when we, you know, we take the month to celebrate it.
And I do believe it's February, the shortest month.
No, that's Black History Month.
That's Black History Month.
(Soundbite of laughter)
That's Black History.
The women is March, right?
I'm sorry, I'm marginalizing everyone at this point.
But I think that - yeah, we should.

Absolutely, and I think that why we don't is part of the reason we're having this discussion is as you look at things and as women look at their goals, unless women are - you know, the people in power making the decisions instead of, you know, white guys, we are going to still have a Women's History Month, you know.

It's that women need to start being on the boards and being able to make the decisions in colleges and in corporations, and nonprofits where they are the one saying we need to focus on women's issues and put them at the forefront of our society, certainly.
Candy, thanks very much for the phone call.
Thank you.
Could I jump in here for a second?
This is Susan.
Go ahead, please.
